advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.<

computer.description:
The Atari 800XL, together with the 600XL, were successors of the Atari 400/800 series and the unsuccessful Atari 1200 XL in a more compact case. They could use almost the same software, just so long as the program was written correctly, because of some slight differences between OS versions.
The 800XL had 64 KB of RAM, two joystick ports and kept all the custom chips (Pokey, GTIA, Antic) of the previous models. It also featured the new Parallel Bus Interface (PBI) providing high speed access to the system bus. The new version of the graphic Antic chip offered 16 graphics modes instead of 12 for the 800.
An enhanced version, called 800XLF, appeared in summer 1984. It was equipped with the new "Freddie" chip which allowed faster memory management, especially for graphics display. This version was released in Europe with SECAM video interface.
Alongside the Commodore 64 and the Apple II, the 600 and 800XL were among the most popular home computers. They would be replaced in 1985 with the XE series when Atari launched the ST. _______________________

emulator.name: The Atari 800 Emulator for the Mac

emulator.description: Unix based emulator of the Atari eight bit computers, namely the Atari 400 and 800, the Atari 400XL, 800XL and 130XE, and the Atari 5200 game console
emulator.name: Atari++

emulator.description: Atari800 is an Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE
emulator.name: Atari800

item.description: Indus GT|||5''/14 disk-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INDUS GT</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;5''/14 disk-drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Indus GT Double Density Drive is considered by many the best floppy drive available for the 8-bit Atari's with its digital readouts and smoke plexi cover.<

Astra 2001 FD unit|||Dual 5.25|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ASTRA 2001 FD UNIT</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Dual 5.25</strong><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" FDD unit using single side, single or double density floppy drives <

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> <

1090 Expansion box #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;1090 EXPANSION BOX #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 1090 is the only expansion or card cage unit ever produced by Atari. It had five internal expansion slots, allowing the user to add five different cards to the PBI bus. Atari was planning to produce many cards for the 1090, but only four - the Atari 1066 CP/M module, a 80-column card, a hard-disk card and a 64K memory board - are known to have reached the prototype stage.<br> A few expansion boxes were built but never sold before the 1090 project was canceled in 1984. <
Complete system||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>As very few top covers were built, a complete expansion box is thus a true rarity! <

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system ! <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!<

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.<

1029 printer #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;1029 PRINTER #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This printer was a modified version of the Seikosha GP-500. Atari replaced the standard Parallel Centronics interface with the custom Atari serial connectors. <br><br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS version with a 7x5 dot matrix head. <br><br> Commodore used same hardware basis for its MPS-801 printer. <

computer.name: 600 / 800 XL
computer.ports: Composite video output, cartridge slot, peripheral port (SIO), parallel bus, 2 joystick plugs
computer.ram: 16 KB (600 XL up to 64 KB) / 64 KB (800 XL, expandable to 128 KB)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;LEFT AND RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Two joystick connectors are located on the right side - The first Atari 800 had four.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • 13-pin serial connector, specific to Atari peripherals (disk drives, tape recorder, printers) which can be connected in chain.<br> • Parallel Bus Interface (PBI), hiden by a plastic lid<br> • Video output DIN socket<br> • TV channel selector<br> • Power in DIN socket and switch. A simple jack would be sufficient as only one 5V voltage is supplied by the external PSU <
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote>To meet US FCC rules, all the active components are covered with metallic protection against magnetic fields.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;800 XLF MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 8 x 4264 chips (64K x 1 bit) hold the 64 KB RAM<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Two ROM chips (24 KB) hold the Atari BASIC interpreter<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> The POKEY chipset can produce complex sounds; it also manages the keyboard<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 6520 I/O chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> 6507 8-bits processor, an evolution of the 6502 using the same instructions set.<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> FREDDIE chipset, in charge of memory management, only available on the 800XLF version.<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b>GTIA and ANTIC custom chipsets, manage the various text and graphic modes. <

computer.text: five text modes, max: 40 x 24, min: 20 x 12
